arm_group.description: In each group, patients received either 0.9% normal saline or plasmalyte solution until end of surgery.
In each group, patients received either 0.9% normal saline or plasmalyte solution until end of surgery.

brief_summary.textblock:
Chloride-rich isotonic crystalloid solutions have been shown to exert electrolyte imbalance
      and metabolic acidosis in critically ill patients. The aim of this investigation is to
      compare the influence of 0.9% saline and plasmalyte solution on acid-base balance and
      electrolytes in healthy patients undergoing major spine surgeries.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Aim of This Investigation is to Compare the Influence of 0.9% Saline and Plasmalyte Solution on Acid-base Balance and Electrolytes in Healthy Patients Undergoing Major Spine Surgeries.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

        1.50 patients (aged 20-65) undergoing cervical or lumbar spine surgery who were diagnosed
        spinal stenosis involving more than tow spinal levels.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          1. ASA class III or IV

          2. pregnancy

          3. breast feeding

          4. lack of mental weakness(including disabled)

          5. using diuretics

          6. respiratory insufficiency

          7. metabolic acidosis or alkalosis

          8. coagulation disorder

          9. over hydtration

         10. renal failure or serum creatinine > 1.4mg/dl

         11. anemia (Hemoglobin 9.0<mg/dl)

         12. hypernatremia (Na > 145mEq/L)

         13. Hyperkalemia (K>5.5mEq/L)

         14. psychological medication or any drugs that influences renal clearance

intervention.description: In each group, patients received either 0.9% normal saline or plasmalyte solution until end of surgery.
In each group, patients received either 0.9% normal saline or plasmalyte solution until end of surgery.

clinical_study.keyword: metabolic acidosis, plasmalyte solution, 0.9% normal saline

facility.name: Department of Anesthesiology and Pain Medicine, Yonsei University College of Medicine

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline in base-excess at postoperative 12 h
